results.title: The Complete Guide to Pointer Events. | by Carlos A. Rojas
Learn Pointer Events In 15 Minutes - YouTube
results.content: for the most part we're taking in our event and our dot and in here really all i want to do is i want to set the position of everything so this is going to be setting our width our height our left our top all those different properties so we can just say for example dot dot style dot width is equal to and we can say e dot width and we're going to put our pixels at the end of that and i'm also just going to multiply this by 10 so it's easy to see because something that's one pixel wide is going to be really hard for you to see so we're just going to multiply it by 10. so it's a little bit easier for you to see we're going to do the same thing with our height and then what we want to do is we want to do our left and our top so our left position here is just going to be our page x and then [...] bug in our code that's because this e dot target should be referencing our timeline instead that'll fix this issue so now wherever we move you can see that this is going in the right place but the problem is if i let go of my mouse i've let go of the mouse down button it's still moving we need to make sure when we lift our pointer up we stop setting this position to do this we can just come in here we can say timeline dot add event listener this is going to be for pointer up and we want to make sure that inside of this all we do is remove our event listener for pointer move so remove event listener pointer move and this is the set timeline position and i want to make sure this pointer up only fires once so we're going to say one's true that should be all we need to do so now if i save and [...] video it's going to be linked over here i highly recommend you check it out it's a great follow-up to this video and if you have seen that i highly recommend you check out my full event listener crash course linked over here it covers everything you need to know about event listeners including some of the more nitty gritty advanced features that most people don't even realize you can do with event listeners with that said thank you very much for watching and have a good day

# Multi-touch interaction

Pointer events extend DOM input events to support various pointing input devices such as pen/stylus and touch screens as well as mouse. The pointer is a hardware-agnostic device that can target a specific set of screen coordinates. Having a single event model for pointers can simplify creating websites, applications and provide a good user experience regardless of the user's hardware. [...] ### Miscellaneous functions

These functions support the application but aren't directly involved with the event flow.

#### Cache management

These functions manage the global event caches evCache1, evCache2 and evCache3.

results.title: PointerEvent - Web APIs | MDN
results.content:
`pointerenter`
:   This event is fired when a pointing device is moved into the hit test boundaries of an element or one of its descendants, including as a result of a `pointerdown` event from a device that does not support hover (see `pointerdown`). This event type is similar to `pointerover`, but differs in that it does not bubble.

`pointerdown`
:   The event is fired when a pointer becomes active. For mouse, it is fired when the device transitions from no buttons pressed to at least one button pressed. For touch, it is fired when physical contact is made with the digitizer. For pen, it is fired when the stylus makes physical contact with the digitizer. [...] Skip to search

Toggle sidebar 

1. Web
2. Web APIs
3. PointerEvent

 

Remember language   Learn more

 Deutsch
 English (US)
 Français
 日本語
 한국어
 中文 (简体)

# PointerEvent

 

Baseline  Widely available  \

This feature is well established and works across many devices and browser versions. It’s been available across browsers since ⁨July 2020⁩.

\ Some parts of this feature may have varying levels of support.

 Learn more
 See full compatibility
 Report feedback

The `PointerEvent` interface represents the state of a DOM event produced by a pointer such as the geometry of the contact point, the device type that generated the event, the amount of pressure that was applied on the contact surface, etc. [...] `pointercancel`
:   A browser fires this event if it concludes the pointer will no longer be able to generate events (for example the related device is deactivated).

`pointerout`
:   This event is fired for several reasons including: pointing device is moved out of the hit test boundaries of an element; firing the `pointerup` event for a device that does not support hover (see `pointerup`); after firing the `pointercancel` event (see `pointercancel`); when a pen stylus leaves the hover range detectable by the digitizer.

`pointerleave`
:   This event is fired when a pointing device is moved out of the hit test boundaries of an element. For pen devices, this event is fired when the stylus leaves the hover range detectable by the digitizer.

# Support w3c pointer events api #1354

New issue

Open

Support w3c pointer events api#1354

Copy link

Labels

cat: event-handlingneeds: feedbacktype: feature

## Description [...] ## Description

allforabit

opened on Jul 4, 2017

Issue body actions

It would be nice to have support for the Pointer events api:  With this it's possible to detect which device is being used for input, e.g. a stylus. Most browsers now support it apart from Safari. However there is a polyfill to work around this: 

OSUblake, simonemazzoni, nicholaswmin, namwkim, LittleHuba and 2 more
